captions.text: Waddup Food Tuber's. Jamie Oliver here. We are gonna make
the best South American style brunch. It's very healthful, it's very colorful

it perfect for the summer when you look
beautiful fresh ingredients

I'm gonna be hero-ing this ingredient
here. Quinoa.
This is from Bolivia, Peru. This

is one of the earliest cultivated grains
on the planet and
it's kind of how you cook it, getting the textures right, and how you dress it.

And then you can use it generically from
sweet to savoury.

as a side dish and a salad. As a kind of
complementary part of any dish.

You're gonna love it. So let me show you
this brunch. Very, very nice.

Let's start with the Quinoa. We're
going to cover it in some water.
We're gonna boil it sort of
fairly hard. The seed will sort of

swell and then like a little kind of shoot
will kind of cook out of it.

It would take about 15-20 minutes to
cook. Moving on.
black beans I wanna go to kinda crispy. I wanna kinda puffy
crack it and puff it up. So we're gonna go into a hot pan with a little olive oil

I'm just gonna put a pinch of cumin, but
little pinch that's what I love about
cooking man.

The tiniest pinch in the world right is
gonna make all the difference
And just put enough flat beans in there to fry.
Would you like me to clean you?
Come here.
So let these beans fry a little bit, a little pinch of salt.
As soon as they get crispy we're gonna turn that heat off. See how nice and light, they're almost like
little peanuts.
Ok. Once they have got crispy just put them to one side.
Like that. You can see the Quinoa boiling away.

and that's fine takes about 15-20
minutes to cook. Okay chillies.

You can just chop them up by all means.
Pop them into a little ball,

so a really nice pinch of salt, and I'm
gonna cover that

with a little bit of sugar. Just to sweeten it lightly
and a little bit

of vinegar. I'm just gonna scrunch that
around. Don't worry about the seeds.

You can even remove those or just go
with it I'm literally just gonna toss that up.
Also it makes fabulous Chile vinegar, so you don't have to throw any of it away.
Oh, by the way. Lets talk about Quinoa. It is basically
low in fat, it's incredibly nutritious, high in iron,
it's also high in zync, it's gluten-free
so really, really good thing. In actual fact you should really all try it.
So the Quinoa had about 20 minutes to cook. You know it's cooked when you just nip
a bit,
taste a bit, it should be soft and delicious

you can see it's kind of plumped up, we're
gonna drain that now.
The residual heat, the steam,

will also help to fluffen it up. Have a
little look at it,  you can see is really plumped
up
I'm going to lay that out.
On a tray.
Look at that. As it steams it'll start to kind of get fluffier,

it'll become lighter so it's
nice and delicate.

Olive oil. Just a little little squeeze of
lemon juice.

Little pinch of salt, and that's a really good
basic Quinoa
Can use it sweet or savoury. Erm, you can use it
as a side dish, as a salad.
So, pan on a low heat, couple of fried eggs. I like the way that it's kinda crispy on the bottom
and just soft and silky on the top

Gonna get that beautiful nice little
pile there you can see

how lovely and light that is. Look at that.
Very beautiful.

Just on the side like that, and of course
I'm gonna just give it a little
poke. A nice little pile of the crispy black beans here.
Half an avocado. We've got some beautiful tomatoes here.

So have a look down the market's see
what you've got available.
Mint and coriander. Nice little wodge like that.
These chiles, we'll take some of that.

and this little vinegar here is gold
dust
so we'll just put that over the avocado.
Some spring onions do help the story
So there you go guys. A beautiful brunch of Quinoa, crispy black beans all those
wonderful summery things like tomatoes, spring onions, jalapenos, the avocado

really really nice and of course because
we haven't got enough chilli in this story
already

just a little bit of chilli sauce as
well
as a little drizzle of olive oil
There you go. Absolutely gorgeous.
Something a bit different,

and a little homage to our South American
Mexican brothers and sisters
Beautiful. You've never tried it
Have a go.
if you like this video please like it
and comment on the comment box. Tell us what you want. What you want me to do for you.

That's what it's all about. Thanks very
much guys, and don't get a lot more
receipes go to jamieoliver.com
Take care. Bye!

title: Healthy South American Brunch | Jamie Oliver | #10HealthyMeals

comments.author: Natalie P.

comments.text:
Hi, I'm from Chile and we eat a lot of quinoa, it's such a great 
ingredient. I use it sometimes instead of rice because it has a lower GI 
(Glycemic index), that's good to loose weight. The only thing is that you 
have to wash and rinse quinoa always before cooking, and then preparing it 
like rice (1 part quinoa, 1 1/2 parts boiling water, low heat and the lid 
on for 20 minutes). I make an awesome quinoa tabbouleh, also have eaten a 
"quinoto", a risotto made with quinoa.
Love the channel!﻿

MMM I AM COLOMBIAN AND NOT ALWAYS WE EAT BEANS, MAYBE SOME REGIONS BUT NOT

 I BELIEVE IN ALL COUNTRIES AND CONTINENTS ARE ALL THE SAME INGREDIENTS BUT

comments.author: leomarbella

comments.text:
I opened a restaurant 6 months ago in a tiny village (475 people) in SW of 
France and I must confess that I am no trained chef, just decided to live 
my passion, you could say I am a prolific cook who is devored by my passion 
.. my clients are happy, my food is cooked with love and Jamie you inspired 
many of my dishes. I wish I was younger and could go back to school and be 
one of your student. but I am 50 in a couple of months and all I can do is 
seat in front of my screen and watch your tips and great ideas... thanks 
for sharing your enthousiasm﻿
comments.author: Florence db

comments.text:
Hey everyone! I'm from South America and one very important detail, you 
HAVE TO, ALWAYS, rinse the quinoa before start cooking it. 
If you don't, you will get a lot of bitterness in the mix.
My two cents.
Have fun!! Cheers!﻿
comments.author: El Cocinero

comments.text:
Hey Jaime! I'm from Chile (South America) and I love your work but please, 
PLEASE NEVER EVER use spain music to characterize South American Food 
PLEASE!!! If you are going to use Quinoa, it would be great to use Bolivian 
music.
(By the way, I looked up and the name of the spain group of musicians is 
"Hermano Lobo", not "HermanDo Lobo")
Production team! Please, do your homework.﻿
comments.author: Antonio Meres

comments.text:
agree, as a Bolivian I think the same. It is complicated that you promote a 
dish from an entire continent. Maybe we use similar ingredients but there 
is no dish that is eaten commonly in every country in South America, we 
differ much in culture.

Thanks for the recipe, it is actually pretty good

comments.author: Danikza Perez-Toledo

comments.text:
I LOVE the recipes I get from Jaime Oliver and food tube but I've got to 
say olive oil is either his favorite thing in the world or his signature 
touch to every meal. Anyway, this dish has a bit of Latin american 
influence but I don't think ANYBODY in south or central america has ever 
eaten this. Quinoa yes, chilis yes (we don't use much that small red chili 
that much because I believe we have so many other wonderful types of 
chili), black beans yes (not prepared that way but yes), avocado of course, 
and everything else is just international I guess... and I mean Tabasco 
sauce? It's not even made in south america or in Mexico for that matter! 
But one thing is for sure, this dish does taste great!﻿

comments.text:
Oh dear... where do I start? this is definitely NOT a real South American 
brunch. I do not want to offend anyone here. I mean, black beans fried on 
olive oil? here in my country, we do eat black beans, but not that way, it 
is a sin to ruin them like that! And what's with the chili salad?? 
Coriander and spring onions are alright, but seriously. a little more 
research wouldn't hurt...﻿

comments.author: Cristian Dixon

comments.text:
I finally made this with high expectations and half way through I thought - 
I use these ingredients all the time and living in California, I make some 
type of Mexican breakfast regularly - so why would I think this was going 
to be different? WOW, was I surprised! This is delicious and somehow 
totally different from my usual combinations of the same ingredients. I 
didn't have mint so I'll try that next time and the only other thing I 
changed was instead of the lemon I used a whole lime and the zest too for 
the quinoa. The sheet pan isn't necessary if you do 2 parts water to 1 part 
quinoa, no draining just cook 15 to 20 minutes till it absorbs the water 
and then set aside covered and it will get all fluffy, then just add the 
citrus right before serving. The chiles in the vinegar mixture were life 
altering and I will use the black bean technique over and over again. As 
Jamie would say BRILLIANT!!﻿
comments.author: Nancy F McCune

comments.text: Most importantly Quinoa is a complete protein!! :) ﻿

Jamie...I believe that you are a great cook, but not quite in 
geography....Peru and Bolivia is far away from México...and México is in

from there to the Patagonia starts and ends South America....keep doing 
this!...I believe is great!....﻿
comments.author: Arturo Jimenez

comments.text:
Jamie, I love Food Tube, keep up! I live in Chile and never seen a meal 
like this in my life, in fact in my country are not used black beans, 
nobody around here likes them, I think they are used in Mexico, which is 
located in North America and also used in Brazil. On the Quinoa, I'd like 
to give it a try, never thought you can cook with it, always heard about it 
as a medicine. I guess this meal is obviously an invention of yours, 
congratulations. Cheers from the southern part of South America.

comments.author: Marcio Florez

comments.text:
Oh by the way... Quinua or Quinoa .. need to be washed ... it has natural 
bitter flavor... wash it on a sifter at least 7 times or until water runs 
clear... another tip bring water to the boil and add the quinua for a 
couple min then drain the water reserve the quinua.. once again boil some 
water and add the quinua which was previously boiled until cooked. This 
will make sure the bitterness go away. And will taste so much better...
comments.author: Marcio Florez

comments.text: Quinoa or quinua is originally from Perú.... not Chile.
